d33cedce-30f9-435d-9220-711135936875.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
d33cedce-30f9-435d-9220-711135936875.chunk:
So, let us conclude our discussion on 
sorting by looking at some other issues.
  So, one of the issues is something called 
stability. So, very often we are not sorting   single values, but we are sorting compound values. 
So, imagine that we have a table

9454b6be-be8b-4bb8-a907-3e046eb753d0.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
9454b6be-be8b-4bb8-a907-3e046eb753d0.chunk:
and we are   sorting the rows in the table. So, each element 
that we want to sort corresponds to one row. So,   one row usually corresponds to values from many 
columns. So, it is a tuple of values. It could be,   for example, a list of students, and eac

f246d6f0-3687-4ecf-b6fc-8515e8073ff5.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
f246d6f0-3687-4ecf-b6fc-8515e8073ff5.chunk:
h student 
has along the columns, you have roll number, you   have the name, you have the marks, and so on.
So, you can think of what you are sorting is   actually a spreadsheet. So, your list is a list 
of rows. But each element in your list consists of

2a124b6b-4c8a-46bf-8580-a50fd368f78c.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
2a124b6b-4c8a-46bf-8580-a50fd368f78c.chunk:
some sub-parts. So, now when 
we sort, we typically sort   on one or more of these sub-parts. The sub-parts 
are attributes or columns. So, you might want to   sort by name or you might want to sort by roll 
number or you might want to sort by marks. 
  A

f55d3fd3-fcb1-43fd-abd5-2520fb59e95d.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
f55d3fd3-fcb1-43fd-abd5-2520fb59e95d.chunk:
nd quite often you might want to sort something 
which has already been sorted. So, for instance,   it could be that your list is 
provided to you by roll number.   And now, for whatever reason 
you want to group the students   in alphabetical order of nam

f0c8729e-e3c2-4fcd-9fde-460dac4922ca.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
f0c8729e-e3c2-4fcd-9fde-460dac4922ca.chunk:
e. So, you 
sort them by alphabetical order of name.
  Now, the question is, when I sort by alphabetical 
order of name, I might get two students who have   the same name. They would have had a roll number. 
In the original sorting one of them would have

2fd68794-9ca7-4a81-9978-b068c4ba2f54.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
2fd68794-9ca7-4a81-9978-b068c4ba2f54.chunk:
a smaller roll number than the other. In the new 
sorting by name, are the roll number still in the   same order or not or have they got shuffled. 
So, this is something that we want to know. So,   for example, supposing you have sorted in 
alphabetical o

6a96e367-4c80-45a4-9395-eb7db57a08a6.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
6a96e367-4c80-45a4-9395-eb7db57a08a6.chunk:
rder of name and now you want   to sort by marks, now when you get the same 
students with the same marks, are they sorted   in alphabetical order of name or do they get 
shuffled? So, this is called stable sorting.
  So, stability says that when I sort in

4540de9b-a440-46e1-a71f-22c555e36666.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
4540de9b-a440-46e1-a71f-22c555e36666.chunk:
another 
column, it should not disturb the sorting on a   previous column. So, later sorting should not 
disturb an earlier thing. And this is something   which is quite natural if you actually work 
with sorted things in spreadsheets and all that.   If y

f7b2b125-da84-4e7c-b710-12526b086b08.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
f7b2b125-da84-4e7c-b710-12526b086b08.chunk:
ou sort on something, you do not want 
to go back and figure out that something   else has got sorted badly that you had 
already sorted in a previous column.
  So, unfortunately, the quicksort implementation 
that we looked at is not going to be stable,

606a4d05-8393-47ee-8d8a-f6e45ee2fd14.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
606a4d05-8393-47ee-8d8a-f6e45ee2fd14.chunk:
because it does all this, if you remember, 
you suddenly do these kinds of exchanges.   So, if these values originally were in 
some order with respect to some value you   are not using right now for sorting and if, while 
partitioning your sort of swappi

4891eada-b55e-49d9-838d-46afdeadeffb.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
4891eada-b55e-49d9-838d-46afdeadeffb.chunk:
ng things around,   then you might very well be exchanging 
things which are equal in some other key   and this is not good. So, the partitioning 
of quicksort has to be very carefully done   to make sure that it is stable. It is possible to 
do it, but no

64cda3b6-26e8-40fa-938e-605de1cd3138.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
64cda3b6-26e8-40fa-938e-605de1cd3138.chunk:
t the partitioning that we saw.
  Merge sort is easier to do. Basically, what you 
want to make sure is that when I have something   like 1, 3, 7 and merge it with, say, 2, 7, 9. So, 
maybe this had an A and this had a B with it. So,   I want to make sure

68d699d0-b999-4722-bac7-4a3d8bce2ea6.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
68d699d0-b999-4722-bac7-4a3d8bce2ea6.chunk:
that in the final list the A7 
comes before the B7 this is what stability means.   It means that in the final list I want 1, 2, 3, 
7, 7, 9, but the order of the 7s should be in the   same order in which I was presented to me in the 
beginning. I should no

c9817ea6-1f2e-4c66-be82-7785511d31b8.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
c9817ea6-1f2e-4c66-be82-7785511d31b8.chunk:
t have 7B followed by 7A,   even though A and B are not part of 
my current sorting procedure. So,   I am not looking at the A and B, but I want 
to guarantee that this does not happen.
  So, in merge, what you do is, basically, if I 
see the same value on

54ca9499-2945-4495-8517-560c68b5ead0.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
54ca9499-2945-4495-8517-560c68b5ead0.chunk:
both sides, then I will   move the one from the left first. So, the value 
from the right should not overtake the value on   the left. If you guarantee that that your merge 
has this kind of preference for the left list,   when you compare equal values, t

a388eddb-d765-48c5-8776-bc6a14cd3fa5.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
a388eddb-d765-48c5-8776-bc6a14cd3fa5.chunk:
hen 
you will get a stable merge.
  Now, we have looked at basically 
criteria which involve the number of   comparisons and swaps that we make. But there 
are situations where actually the data has to   physically be moved and it is not an easy thing 
to

c5d06dad-09e5-4488-9ee4-c245d2a309e1.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
c5d06dad-09e5-4488-9ee4-c245d2a309e1.chunk:
move data from one place to another. So,   you can imagine that the data 
sitting in some heavy boxes. 
  So, supposing you are doing a physical sorting or 
something, then one of the things that you might   want to minimize is not just the number of boxes

1019dd7c-fb2b-420e-b5c5-5aff98152f07.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
1019dd7c-fb2b-420e-b5c5-5aff98152f07.chunk:
you examine and exchange, you might be willing to   look at more boxes to examine and exchange 
if you have to move your boxes overall.
  So, data movement is an orthogonal thing 
compared to anything that we have discussed   so far. But this is also an

23866174-7ed4-49b6-a15a-61d167277768.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
23866174-7ed4-49b6-a15a-61d167277768.chunk:
important criterion 
when looking at certain categories of sorting. So,   sorting is a fairly vast. As we said, sorting 
is used as a first step for a large number of   things and there are many different dimensions 
to sorting which people have looked at.

a70f6841-61c2-4ee9-8feb-4aa95ce08b12.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
a70f6841-61c2-4ee9-8feb-4aa95ce08b12.chunk:
So, you should not think that if you 
know merge sort and quicksort you have   exhausted everything to do with sorting. 
There is a lot of sorting which is still   there and many different ways of sorting which 
emphasize different aspects of the probl

e2c807f4-923b-4a2c-83d1-8d59c8f5d120.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
e2c807f4-923b-4a2c-83d1-8d59c8f5d120.chunk:
em.
  So, is there a best sorting algorithm? 
Well, as you can see from our discussion,   the hints are quite clear that there is no 
best sorting algorithm overall. Quicksort is,   as we said, very often the algorithm of choice 
when we are using built in

7c7c7904-1cfb-45ef-b385-cf29f3fc90e7.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
7c7c7904-1cfb-45ef-b385-cf29f3fc90e7.chunk:
functions and all that   people use quicksort, despite its worst case. 
But there are situations, like we were talking   about those boxes, where you do not have the 
luxury of sorting everything as a function.   So, sometimes you need to sort, example in

5d7b18b5-a1ce-455f-ac3f-b2b070164c04.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
5d7b18b5-a1ce-455f-ac3f-b2b070164c04.chunk:
a database, and in a database you need to   put parts of the data into memory and part 
out. So, this is called external sorting.
  So, usually, merge sort is used for external 
sorting. And merge sort is not the only n log   n algorithm. There is also a

c035e59d-481a-41ce-9e16-270b71ea3aac.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
c035e59d-481a-41ce-9e16-270b71ea3aac.chunk:
n algorithm 
which we will see later called heapsort,   which also does n log n. So, there are other n log 
n algorithms. And very often, you might actually   use a hybrid strategy. So, you might use a divide 
and conquer strategy when n is large. But then

83f2e635-0387-4d42-b837-fd7cfa0625c2.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
83f2e635-0387-4d42-b837-fd7cfa0625c2.chunk:
when you get down to a small list, say like 16 or 
32, you might switch over to insertion sort.
  So, a lot of different ways are there of 
combining algorithms or using the properties of,   sorting algorithm for different situations. So, 
you, it is us

e500f52e-23ec-4edc-89e0-d5725afd5126.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
e500f52e-23ec-4edc-89e0-d5725afd5126.chunk:
eful to know that all these exist.   Although in many cases, you will typically 
be using a built-in sorting routine. So,   you do not really need to know the sorting 
algorithm as long as a built-in sort function   works. But there are situations where yo

f95c93ef-bbf8-45e6-8f5a-db881ca67351.title: Concluding Remarks on Sorting Algorithms
f95c93ef-bbf8-45e6-8f5a-db881ca67351.chunk:
u will
